alerts.title: Visitors to Great Barrier Reef reminded to be SharkSmart
alerts.description: Visitors to the Great Barrier Reef islands and beaches reminded to be SharkSmart:
alerts.details:
Visitors to the Great Barrier Reef islands and beaches reminded to be SharkSmart:

  • Don't swim at dawn or dusk
  • Always swim in clear water (not in murky water, busy anchorages, estuary mouths or canals)
  • Don't throw food scraps or fish waste overboard or into the water from the beach (including in anchorages or where people are swimming)
  • Don't swim where fish are being cleaned
  • Swim, surf, snorkel or dive with a buddy.

For more information visit https://www.daf.qld.gov.au/sharksmart

alerts.title: Permanent fire prohibition on Teewah Beach
alerts.description: A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.
alerts.details:
A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.

This permanent fire prohibition was implemented to reduce the risk of bushfires, protect critical habitat of native wildlife, enhance visitor safety from campfire related injuries and reduce rubbish from non-combustible materials being burnt.

Fully enclosed cooking and heating appliances can still be used in camping areas that meet the below requirements.

  • The appliance must use gas or manufactured fuel (heat beads, briquettes). Manufactured fuel does not include timber or wood.
  • It must be used only for cooking and/or heating.
  • It must be a minimum of 20cm off the ground and more than 2m from flammable materials, which includes vegetation. 
  • It must not have the potential to generate airborne embers, or possibly ignite nearby ground fuels.
  • It must be fully self-contained (heat source enclosed and no exposed flame) and never left unattended when in use.
  • Appliances that are not fully self-contained, such as braziers, are not permitted.
  • All appliances, materials and burnt fuel must be removed from the recreation area on your departure.

On the spot fines of $774 can be issued to people who light fires during a fire prohibition.

Campfires are permitted at Poverty Point camping area and at nearby Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area unless in accordance with all local directions for that area.

For details on the difference between a Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) total fire ban and a QPWS fire prohibition and approved cooking appliances visit the DES Camp fires and cooking web page.

QPWS thanks you for your cooperation while we implement this management change.

alerts.title: North West Island declaration of Special Activity Area (Sharks)
alerts.description: A new Special Activity Area has been declared at North West Island, Capricornia Cays National Park in accordance with Section 128 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.
alerts.details:
A new Special Activity Area has been declared at North West Island, Capricornia Cays National Park in accordance with Section 128 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.

This applies to the area surrounding North West Island on North West Island Reef to reduce the risk of humans interacting with sharks. Within the special activity area shown on the map (https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/capricornia-cays/maps-resources)

You must not:

  • attract sharks by any means or methods to have a close interaction
  • process fish product
  • dump fish scraps
  • clean fish processing equipment.

Penalties may apply if you do any of these activities without prior permission or agreement under Section 132 of the Marine Parks Regulation 2017.

alerts.title: Dingo (Wongari) Seasonal Information - Breeding Season
alerts.description: Following the autumn mating season, many female wongari (dingoes) will be pregnant. Gestation takes about 9 weeks and litters of 110 pups (normally 46) are born and cared for (whelped) during the winter months.
alerts.details:
Following the autumn mating season, many female wongari (dingoes) will be pregnant. Gestation takes about 9 weeks and litters of 110 pups (normally 46) are born and cared for (whelped) during the winter months.

Once new-born pups arrive, their parents may be aggressive. They need to find food for themselves and their pups. Remember give dingoes space, K’gari is their place.

Visitors, tour operators and residents are advised to Be Dingo-safe! on K’gari. It is recommended that families with young children camp in fenced QPWS camping areas at Lake Boomanjin, Central Station, Dundubara, Waddy Point, and eastern beach fenced area (Wongai, One Tree Rocks, Cornwells, Eli), or at fenced private camping areas at Dilli Village or Cathedral Beach.

Let young wongari (dingoes) grow up wild - not reliant on handouts. Do not feed wongari (dingoes) or leave food available. Every time a wongari (dingo) receives food from people, its chance of survival is reduced.

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • Always stay close (within arm’s reach) of children and young teenagers.
  • Always walk in groups and carry a stick.
  • Camp in fenced areas where possible.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Never feed dingoes.
  • Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on a boat).
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.

Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@des.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest QPWS ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150 – mobile phone charges may apply. Take note of location, vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number and which ear.

For further information about wongari (dingoes) on K’gari (Fraser Island) please visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

alerts.title: Camper Hygiene
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) reminds campers of the need to maintain high personal hygiene standards whilst camping in the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) reminds campers of the need to maintain high personal hygiene standards whilst camping in the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.

QPWS would like to remind all visitors to maintain high personal hygiene, including washing hands frequently with soap and water, particularly after visiting the toilet, when preparing food and before eating and after visiting waste disposal and water point sites.

For the health and wellbeing of our park visitors and staff, and to limit the spread of illness visitors are recommended to:

  • Wash hands often with soap and water, especially before preparing food, eating and after going to the toilet (viral and bacterial stomach illnesses are not prevented with alcohol-based sanitisers).
  • Ensure all campers have a personal towel for hand drying.
  • Cover your coughs and sneezes with your elbow or a tissue.
  • Ensure your campsite is located away from other tents.
  • Where possible, bring your own portable toilet (mandatory for Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas)
  • Keep your rubbish secure and dispose in bins provided or take home.
  • Stay at home if you or any members of your group are unwell.
  • Keep a personal supply of drinking and washing water during your stay. 

Check Park Alerts regularly for updates on current park conditions.

alerts.title: Portable toilets mandatory for Teewah Beach camping zones
alerts.description: All campers staying within the Teewah Beach camping zones 1 to 7 must bring and use a portable toilet for the duration of their stay. A minimum of one portable toilet per camping permit holder is required.
alerts.details:
All campers staying within the Teewah Beach camping zones 1 to 7 must bring and use a portable toilet for the duration of their stay. A minimum of one portable toilet per camping permit holder is required.

Portable toilets must have a sealed waste holding tank and must be transportable and suitable for emptying into a portable toilet waste disposal facility. Bag and open bucket style toilets are not permitted. 

Disposal waste facilities are available for use by campers at the following locations:

  • Second cutting, Noosa North Shore.
  • Freshwater day-use area, (beach camper service bay).
  • Clarkson Drive, Rainbow Beach.

Note: This is a permanent management change for Teewah Beach. 

It is an offence to camp at Teewah Beach camping area without a portable toilet, penalties apply.

alerts.title: Threatening dingo activity - Eli Creek, Waddy Point and Wathumba
alerts.description: Instances of threatening dingo behaviour have been reported at some locations including Eli Creek, Waddy Point and Wathumba.
alerts.details:
Instances of threatening dingo behaviour have been reported at some locations including Eli Creek, Waddy Point and Wathumba.

Visitors, tour operators and residents are advised to be dingo-safe! on Fraser Island.

Locations of threatening dingo behaviour:

  • Happy Valley to Cathedral Beach (including beach camping areas)
  • Eli Creek
  • Waddy Point to Ngkala Rocks (including beach camping areas)
  • Wathumba
  • Western beach camping areas

It is recommended that visitors be extra vigilant in these areas. Consider camping in fenced QPWS camping areas.

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.des.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • NEVER feed dingoes.
  • Always stay within arm’s reach of children, even small teenagers.
  • Walk in groups and carry a stick.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Camp in fenced areas when possible.
  • Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on a boat).
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.
  • Secure all rubbish, fish and bait.
  • No food to lakeshores.

Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@des.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest QPWS ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150 – mobile phone charges may apply. Take note of location, vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number and which ear.

 

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Bribie Islands northern breakaway section remains part of the recreation area
alerts.description: In early 2022, a new coastal bar was cut through Bribie Island 2kms from the northern end of Bribie Island Recreation Area, separating the park into two sections.
alerts.details:
In early 2022, a new coastal bar was cut through Bribie Island 2kms from the northern end of Bribie Island Recreation Area, separating the park into two sections.

This northern breakaway section of Bribie Island remains part of the Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area. While the national park boundary remains at the high tide mark, the recreation area boundary extends down to the mean low water mark and moves with the accretion and erosion of the sand. Newly formed sandbars and vegetated dunes at this northern breakaway section fall within the recreation area boundary.

Boaties and mainland residents are reminded that this northern breakaway section is not suitable for dog walking.

All national park and recreation area regulations continue to be enforceable including dogs, fires and camping being prohibited from this section of the recreation area.

Rangers will be patrolling this area and can issue fines for anyone caught breaching park rules.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Unstable sand cliffs and dunes along Rainbow and Teewah beaches
alerts.description: Exposed sand cliffs and sand dunes along Rainbow and Teewah beaches are unstable and can collapse without warning. Falling boulders and landslides are common in this dynamic coastal environment and can result in serious injury or death.
alerts.details:
Exposed sand cliffs and sand dunes along Rainbow and Teewah beaches are unstable and can collapse without warning. Falling boulders and landslides are common in this dynamic coastal environment and can result in serious injury or death.

For your safety and to avoid injuries:

  • Do not climb or dig into sand dunes or sand cliffs.
  • Avoid standing, sitting or parking near the base of the dunes.
  • Always stay well away from the base of sand dunes.
  • Supervise children at all times.

Beach travel is recommended two hours either side of low tide. Travelling three hours either side of high tide should be avoided.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.description: Due to current and ongoing restoration works on the Cunningham Highway, walking tracks and visitor areas at the Cunninghams Gap section of Main Range National Park have been temporarily affected.
alerts.details:
Due to current and ongoing restoration works on the Cunningham Highway, walking tracks and visitor areas at the Cunninghams Gap section of Main Range National Park have been temporarily affected.

The following visitor areas have changed conditions:

  • Access to The Crest carpark will be closed to all traffic from the Cunningham Highway.
  • Visitors are encouraged to park at West Gap Creek picnic area 1.7km west from The Crest carpark.
  • Mount Mitchell track will be closed to all visitors from 6pm Friday 6 September to 5am Tuesday 10 September.
  • All Cunningham Gap section walking tracks start from the West Gap Creek picnic area, via the Box Forest track. This includes Mount Cordeaux, Bare Rock and the Rainforest circuit tracks. Walkers need to be aware of the extra 5km this will add to their intended walk. 
  • Visitors are reminded that parking along the Cunningham Highway is prohibited. 

Road conditions and roadworks signage may vary depending on the stage of construction, and visitors are asked to follow all instructions and drive safely to road conditions.

For more information, please visit the Department of Transport and Main Roads website: Cunningham Highway (Ipswich – Warwick), 2020 Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements reconstruction works | Department of Transport and Main Roads (tmr.qld.gov.au).

Please monitor Queensland Traffic for updated information regarding road and traffic conditions.

For your safety please slow down and observe all directions and signs.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.details:
The easternmost campsite of Snapper Island remains closed following damage from Cyclone Jasper in December 2023.

The other three campsites have been reopened and are available to book. The island has also been reopened for day use.

The island is open with caution; please be aware that there is still some debris around the sites and internal tracks, and noticeable cyclone damage to the island. Rangers have worked to ensure that visitor infrastructure is safe. The easternmost campsite will be reopened once additional works have been completed.

alerts.title: Helicopter operations for the Wangetti Trail Project, Palm Cove to Wangetti
alerts.description: Construction works are currently underway on the southern section of the Wangetti Trail, from Palm Cove to Ellis Beach, including within Macalister Range National Park. As construction works progress, helicopters will be used to deliver materials and equipment into remote and challenging sections of the trail.
alerts.details:
Construction works are currently underway on the southern section of the Wangetti Trail, from Palm Cove to Ellis Beach, including within Macalister Range National Park. As construction works progress, helicopters will be used to deliver materials and equipment into remote and challenging sections of the trail.

These helicopter operations are expected to commence January 2024, and occur Monday to Friday during daylight hours.

Helicopter operations may occur up to four times per day until August 2024, from two lift areas:

  • Existing Helicopter Pad at SES Depot Buchan's Point
  • Heli-lift Depot at Mowbray.

In order to minimise disruption to surrounding residential areas, the flight path from SES Buchan's Point will be north along the Ellis Beach powerline easement, as far as Ellis Beach.

For more information on the Wangetti Trail Project, visit www.dtis.qld.gov.au/wangettitrail

alerts.details:

alerts.title: Extended baiting program for feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park, Dryander National Park, Dryander State Forest and Dryander Forest Reserve
alerts.description: The Department of Environment, Science and Innovation is undertaking a ground baiting program from 24 February 2024 to 24 February 2025. Manufactured baits will be used to control feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park (Lot 43 on NPW1144 and Lot 1 on NPW1145), Dryander National Park (Lot 24 on AP19346), Dryander State Forest (Lot 432 on AP19346) and Dryander Forest Reserve (Lot 5 on AP19346). Notices will be placed at the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service office at Jubilee Pocket and the Whitsunday Regional Council offices at Proserpine and Cannonvale for one week prior to each baiting event. These notices will remain in place for four weeks after baiting has finished. Notices will also be placed at the entrances of the Conway Circuit on Conway National Park and at Double Bay on Dryander National Park. A Park Alert will also be placed on the Department of Environment, Science and Innovation website (www.des.qld.gov.au) for the same period. Dogs and other domestic animals are not allowed within protected areas. Steps must be taken to ensure domestic dogs do not gain access to the baits or poisoned animals. Neighbours should restrain dogs and other domestic animals during baiting programs. For more information, please contact the department on 13 QGOV (13 74 68).

alerts.title: Camp site booking restrictions due to tidal inundation
alerts.description: Several low-lying camp sites adjacent to Pumicestone Passage on the western side of Bribie Island Recreation Area will be closed on a recurring basis throughout 2024 due to tidal inundation from forecast large high tides.
alerts.details:
Several low-lying camp sites adjacent to Pumicestone Passage on the western side of Bribie Island Recreation Area will be closed on a recurring basis throughout 2024 due to tidal inundation from forecast large high tides.

Affected camp sites include:

  • Lime Pocket camping area - All sites
  • Mission Point camping area - Sites 1-6 
  • Gallagher Point camping area - All sites
  • Poverty Creek camping area - Sites 4 & 5

Please note heights are taken from the Brisbane Bar tide chart. This is due to the changes in water flow caused by the northern breakaway section of Bribie Island.

On waterfront sites campers should, where possible, consider placing tents and camping equipment back from the water’s edge to avoid any inundation from passing boats.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Stay up to date with weather forecasts, conditions and warnings.

alerts.title: Russell Island camping area closed
alerts.description: Russell Island camping area will be closed until further notice while management authorities make decisions about the future suitability for recreational infrastructure in this area.
alerts.details:
Russell Island camping area will be closed until further notice while management authorities make decisions about the future suitability for recreational infrastructure in this area.

Erosion has significantly affected the northern beach of the low-lying sandy portion of Russell Island. This was exacerbated by Tropical Cyclone Jasper in December 2023. Erosion now threatens the camping area as well as the safe operation and longevity of the toilet block in its current location.

For this reason, Russell Island will be closed for camping indefinitely. The island is still open for day use.

Russell Island is a Commonwealth Island managed jointly by Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

alerts.title: Cooroora Shared Trail 2 entry closed at School Street
alerts.description: In conjunction with Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Partnerships (QPWS&P), the Noosa Council has upgraded the Cooroora Shared Trail 2 as part of the Noosa Trail master plan.
alerts.details:
In conjunction with Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Partnerships (QPWS&P), the Noosa Council has upgraded the Cooroora Shared Trail 2 as part of the Noosa Trail master plan.

Upgrades completed include trail realignment, resurfacing and the moving of the trailhead to allow safer access and better parking options. 

The access point for the Cooroora Shared Trail 2, previously located at the School Street, has moved further west to Mountain Street. The Tuchekoi National Park map has been updated on the website to reflect these changes.

Please note dog walking is not permitted on the trails within Tuchekoi National Park. QPWS rangers do patrol the area and may issue on-the-spot fines for non-compliance.

alerts.details:

alerts.title: Bunya Mountains - Burtons Well walking tracks closed due to storm damage
alerts.description: The Mt Kiangarow track and Burtons Well to Cherry Plain walk are closed, due to damage to the boot-washing station at the track entrance sustained during a severe weather event causing fallen trees.
alerts.details:
The Mt Kiangarow track and Burtons Well to Cherry Plain walk are closed, due to damage to the boot-washing station at the track entrance sustained during a severe weather event causing fallen trees.

Washdown stations help to prevent the spread of Phytophthora, a plant pathogen which causes disease in the Bunya pines. Tracks will re-open when the washdown stations are repaired. 

Alternative walking tracks from Westcott, Paradise carpark and Dandabah remain open to visitors. The Cherry Plain to Westcott track also remains open, although access to the Cherry Plain lookout is closed. 

 

 

 

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for alternative nearby park attractions and experiences.

alerts.title: Planned Burns Woondum National Park
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Partnerships will be conducting planned burns in Woondum National Park from Wednesday 7 February through to Friday 31 August weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests. As a result, smoke may be seen in the Cooran, Pomona, Kin Kin, Traveston, Tandur and Pinbarren areas. The aim of these burns is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas. This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Partnerships will be conducting planned burns in Woondum National Park from Wednesday 7 February through to Friday 31 August weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests. As a result, smoke may be seen in the Cooran, Pomona, Kin Kin, Traveston, Tandur and Pinbarren areas. The aim of these burns is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas. This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration.

 Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions. Please observe signage, barriers, do not enter closed areas and follow direction from rangers. Safety is our concern but your responsibility.

alerts.title: Park Alert - K'gari Planned Burn Season 2024
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns within the Kgari (Fraser Island) section from 12th February 2024  August 31st 2024, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns within the Kgari (Fraser Island) section from 12th February 2024 August 31st 2024, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.

The aim of these burns is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas.  This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration.

As a result, smoke may be seen island-wide, including areas within Kingfisher Bay Resort Village, Dilli Village, Eurong resort & township, Dundubara, Orchid Beach township and Waddy Point.

Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads, so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions. Visitors and residents should close windows and doors and keep medications close by if suffering from a respiratory illness.

For more information, please call Eurong office of QPWS on (07) 4127 9128 or Dundubara office of QPWS on (07) 4127 9138.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Prescribed burn - Exploration Break East
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will conduct prescribed burning activities between 01st March and 31st August 2024, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests. These burns are being undertaken to help protect life and property in the event of a wildfire.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will conduct prescribed burning activities between 01st March and 31st August 2024, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests. These burns are being undertaken to help protect life and property in the event of a wildfire.

Smoke may be seen in the vicinity of Tukkee Wurro (Indian Head), Champagne Pools, Waddy Point, Orchid Beach, beach camping zone 7 (Wyuna, Burad), and zone 8 (Marloo, Ocean Lake, Duling), as well as western camp zones Bowarrady, Awinya, Bowal and Wathumba.

Persons with respiratory or other health problems should seek medical advice on mitigating the effects of smoke inhalation.

Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads, so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions.

Please observe and adhere to all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and contractors, and do not enter closed areas or exclusion zones.

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Planned burn - Binngih Sandblow to Orchid Beach
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) and Butchulla Aboriginal Corporation Rangers will conduct prescribed burn operations within the Kgari (Fraser Island) section of the Great Sandy National Park - Binngih Sandblow to Orchid Beach between Friday 1 March 2024 to Saturday 31 August 2024, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) and Butchulla Aboriginal Corporation Rangers will conduct prescribed burn operations within the Kgari (Fraser Island) section of the Great Sandy National Park - Binngih Sandblow to Orchid Beach between Friday 1 March 2024 to Saturday 31 August 2024, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.

As a result, smoke may be seen in the vicinity of Orchid Beach Township, Waddy Point Camping areas and beach camping zone 8 (Marloo, Ocean Lake, Duling). Persons with respiratory or other health problems should seek medical advice on mitigating the effects of smoke inhalation.

The aim of this burn is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas. This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration.

Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads, so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions.

Please observe and adhere to all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and contractors, and do not enter closed areas or exclusion zones.

For more information, please call the Dundubara QPWS office on 4127 9138.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.title: Portable toilets are mandatory for Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) have introduced mandatory portable toilet requirements at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas (Inskip Point Recreation Area) from 01 June 2024. This initiative had been introduced to address high levels of bush toileting posing an unacceptable risk to the health and safety of campers and visitors and the areas natural environment.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) have introduced mandatory portable toilet requirements at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas (Inskip Point Recreation Area) from 01 June 2024. This initiative had been introduced to address high levels of bush toileting posing an unacceptable risk to the health and safety of campers and visitors and the areas natural environment.

From 01 June 2024, it is an offence to camp at Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas without a portable toilet and penalties will apply. A minimum of one portable toilet per camping permit holder is required. Rangers will be on patrol to monitor compliance and educate campers about the benefits of using portable toilets.

Portable toilets must have a sealed waste holding tank and must be transportable and suitable for emptying into a portable toilet waste disposal facility. Bag and open bucket style toilets are not permitted. 

For your convenience, the Gympie Regional Council portable toilet waste disposal facility is located at Clarkson Drive, Rainbow Beach. Do not dispose of sanitary items, disposable nappies or toilet wipes into the toilet waste disposal facility as these items will block the system. Bag these items and take them home for disposal.

Do not empty your portable toilet waste into any toilets or general waste facilities in the recreation area as it creates a risk to human health and on-the-spot fines apply.

QPWS thanks you for your support and cooperation during this management change.

Note: This is a permanent management change for Pelican Bay and Dorrigo South camping areas. 

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

alerts.title: Annual Cooloola Hazard Reduction Burn Program
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns within the Cooloola area from April - August 2024, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns within the Cooloola area from April - August 2024, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction/conservation management program for parks and forests.

The aim of these burns is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas.  This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration.

As a result smoke may be seen in the vicinity of the Cooloola Recreation Area, Rainbow Beach, Cooloola Cove, Tin Can Bay, Teewah Beach, and Noosa North Shore.

Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads, so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions.  Visitors and residents should close windows and doors, and keep medications close by if suffering from a respiratory illness.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.details:

alerts.title: Safety Advisory Notice: Coomera Falls circuit - High degree of caution required
alerts.description: Due to several compounding severe weather events and ongoing wet conditions the Coomera Falls circuit has sustained significant damage in parts, particularly in the southern section between the Coomera Falls Lookout and the Border track junction.
alerts.details:
Due to several compounding severe weather events and ongoing wet conditions the Coomera Falls circuit has sustained significant damage in parts, particularly in the southern section between the Coomera Falls Lookout and the Border track junction.

It is NOT RECOMMENDED for young children and/or anyone with physical limitations at present, until conditions improve.

  • The section between the Coomera Falls lookout and the junction with the Border track has significant damage to the track surface in parts, including a number of large fallen trees or obstructions, which can be challenging to negotiate, particularly in wet conditions, requiring a high level of experience and care.  Proceed with caution!
  • Creeks may also be swollen and fast-flowing, and rocks may be more slippery than usual.  Take extreme care when attempting creek crossings.  Remember, if it's flooded, forget it (even on walking tracks)!

Whilst the walking track has significant damage in parts, including minor diversions and challenging traverses, it remains within the Grade 4 walking track classification and expectations, in accordance with Australian Standards (AS2156.1-2001).

Please note that whilst the section of walking track from the Binna Burra trailhead to the Coomera Falls lookout is very muddy, it remains easily to moderately traversable.

Rangers are working to rectify and repair the damage.

Observe all signage, barriers, and directions from rangers, and do not enter the closed area.

Always remain on the designated walking track, wherever possible.  Your risk to personal safety increases significantly when straying from the designated walking track.

Please check Park Alerts as they are regularly updated regarding conditions on park.

alerts.title: On water signage in Great Sandy Marine Park
alerts.description: Great Sandy Marine Park users are advised not to rely on the presence of signage to inform them of their location within the various zones of the marine park. Marine Park zones are defined solely by GPS boundary locations, and users must refer to Schedule 1 and 2 of the Marine Parks (Great Sandy) Zoning Plan 2024 for precise boundary descriptions. There are reliable digital platforms which provide all-round coverage and information of all the zones and designated areas for users. eg. Electronic chart systems used on GPS chart plotters, electronic chart Apps used for navigation on smart devices, including Marine SQ App and the QLD Fisheries 2.0 App. Legacy advisory signs installed since 2006 are progressively phased out and updating of the Great Sandy Marine Park printed and web materials will continue to occur progressively.

alerts.title: Temporary closure of beach camping zone 8 for dingo management
alerts.description: Beach camping zone 8 (Marloo, Ocean Lake and Duling) located between Orchid Beach and Ngkala Rocks is temporarily closed from 10 June to 13 September due to increased threatening dingo activity in the area.
alerts.details:
Beach camping zone 8 (Marloo, Ocean Lake and Duling) located between Orchid Beach and Ngkala Rocks is temporarily closed from 10 June to 13 September due to increased threatening dingo activity in the area.

This closure is necessary to reduce negative dingo interactions and allow for ongoing monitoring and dingo management.

For people with camping bookings over this closure period a booking change or refund will be available via the online booking system at www.qld.gov.au/camping.

Alternative camping may be available at Waddy Point Top (fenced) camping area and beach camping zone 7 (Wyuna and Burad). See link for a full list of wongari deterrent fenced camping areas on K’gari.

Visitors are reminded to keep children within arm’s reach and never attempt to feed or touch wongari. These are wild animals and can quickly become aggressive. On-the-spot fines of $2,476.80 apply for anyone caught feeding or disturbing dingoes anywhere on K’gari.

All dingo interactions should be reported to QPWS rangers in person, by emailing dingo.ranger@des.qld.gov.au or phoning (07) 4127 9150. Where possible take note of location, vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number and which ear.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.details:

alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns from June-September when weather conditions are favourable.

Planned burns reduce the volume of fuels in forests and create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas. This will help to reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for native woodland regeneration.

Before any planned burn is undertaken, local stakeholders and booked campers will be informed.

Smoke may be seen coming from the island at times throughout the season. Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads and on the water, so it is important that motorists and vessel masters drive safely to the conditions.

alerts.title: Notification of planned burn  Glass House Mountains National Park
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service intends to conduct a planned burn in the Beerburrum section of Glass House Mountains National Park. This burn is scheduled for the coming weeks, or as soon as weather conditions are favourable.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service intends to conduct a planned burn in the Beerburrum section of Glass House Mountains National Park. This burn is scheduled for the coming weeks, or as soon as weather conditions are favourable.

The following areas will be closed to public access during the burn:

  • Caves Road
  • Mt Beerburrum trailhead and summit walk,
  • Soldier settlers shared trail,
  • Yul-yan-man track, and
  • Trachyte circuit.

Please note: This park alert is a forward notification only. These areas are currently open.

Once the dates of the planned burn is known, detailed information regarding the dates and associated closures will be posted as an additional Park Alert on the Department's website once this information is known. 

This burn is part of our hazard reduction and conservation management program for parks and forests estate. QPWS&P conducts burns to decrease wildfire risk for protection of the community.  Fire is also essential for the health of our native plant communities.

Smoke may be seen in the vicinity of the Beerburrum section of the national park during and after the burn. Persons with respiratory or other health problems should seek medical advice on mitigating the effects of smoke inhalation.

Commercial tour operators and other permit or agreement holders are not permitted to enter closed areas.

If you have any inquiries regarding the planned burn please contact QPWS&P at Maleny on 5494 3983.

Facilities will reopen when conditions are considered safe.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Planned burning activities: Little Mulgrave National Park

alerts.details:
Queensland parks and Wildlife Service will be conducting planned burning activities in Little Mulgrave National Park from Monday 5 August to Saturday 31 August 2024 (dates inclusive). During this period the park is closed to the public.

Targeted areas include isolated ridges within Little Mulgrave National Park adjacent to Mount Peter, as well as Huntsbrook Creek on the Gillies Range. Target burn areas are not within proximity of visitor areas.

Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service rangers introduce fire in favourable conditions utilizing existing and/or natural features such as creeks, roads, firebreaks and high soil moisture areas. The objective of cool season burn operations is to successfully reduce the frequency of wildfires, protect adjacent urban areas and provide a measure of conservation for forest habitat.

alerts.title: Poison canisters washing up on Southeast Queensland beaches
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) is warning visitors of the potential dangers posed by toxic canisters washing up on Queensland beaches.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) is warning visitors of the potential dangers posed by toxic canisters washing up on Queensland beaches.

Since February 2012, emergency services have received reports from the public of small unlabelled canisters washing up on Australian beaches. QPWS continue to receive reports of these canisters washing up on beaches at K’gari, Mulgumpin (Moreton Island) and Minjerribah (North Stradbroke Island).

The canisters contain a rat poison known as ‘aluminium phosphide’, a white to grey solid which is hazardous to humans.

When the canister is opened, the powder reacts with moisture in the air to release phosphine gas, which is also highly toxic to humans. The gas has a strong odour that can smell like garlic, rotting fish or urine, but it can quickly dull the sense of smell.

Exposure can cause symptoms such as headaches, nausea, vomiting, difficulty breathing, dizziness, tightness of the chest, diarrhoea, fluid in the lungs, liver/kidney damage, and in severe cases death.

The gas is also flammable and can spontaneously ignite causing burns or small explosions.

The canisters are silver in colour and approximately 22 centimetres tall. They have a tapered top with a screw in lid. Visit https://www.amsa.gov.au/news-community/news-and-media-releases/poison-canister-warning(external link) for images of the canisters.

Canisters should not be moved or opened, and any sightings should be reported to emergency services on Triple Zero (000).

alerts.title: Feral animal control planned on Minjerribah (North Stradbroke Island)
alerts.description: The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) and Quandamooka Yoolooburrabee Aboriginal Corporation (QYAC) together with members of the Straddie Pest Management Group will be conducting feral animal control measures on North Stradbroke Island from 8 July to 30 September 2024.
alerts.details:
The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) and Quandamooka Yoolooburrabee Aboriginal Corporation (QYAC) together with members of the Straddie Pest Management Group will be conducting feral animal control measures on North Stradbroke Island from 8 July to 30 September 2024.

This integrated feral animal control will include the use of 1080 baits to protect wildlife from predation.

Baiting using 1080 is subject to strict regulatory conditions set down by the Queensland Department of Health and Biosecurity Queensland. No baiting will occur until all required conditions have been met.

Precautionary measures include buffers of townships and residential areas and other mechanisms to protect wildlife and waterways will be in place. 

Residents and visitors to North Stradbroke Island are requested to keep domestic animals under tight control and pay specific attention to any signage during this control period. 

For more information, please contact info@straddiepest.org

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.title: Planned burn season
alerts.description: Planned Burn season.
alerts.details:
Planned Burn season.

Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be conducting planned burns from July-September when weather conditions are favourable.

Planned burns reduce the volume of fuels in forests and create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas. This will help to reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for native woodland regeneration.

Before any planned burn is undertaken, local stakeholders and booked campers will be informed.

Smoke may be seen coming from the Conway and Dryander National Park areas at times throughout the season. Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads and on the water, so it is important that motorists and vessel masters drive safely to the conditions.

Please observe all signage, barriers, and directions from Rangers.

For more information, please contact QPWS&P on 13QGOV (13 74 68).

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Announcement: Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area pest management program for feral animals.
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service & Partnerships (QPWS&P) is continuing to protect critical habitat supporting threatened species on Bribie Island through its pest management program for feral animals.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service & Partnerships (QPWS&P) is continuing to protect critical habitat supporting threatened species on Bribie Island through its pest management program for feral animals.

Feral animals, such as pigs, foxes and horses pose a significant threat to our natural environment by disrupting ecosystems and negatively impacting native species. To address these environmental concerns, we actively engage in annual pest management programs to control their populations and minimise their impact, using a range of control techniques based on National Codes of Practice and Standard Operating Procedures.

Visitor safety is our main priority, which is why during quieter periods, we implement temporary closures of campsites and other sections of Park to conduct necessary pest control activities to meet the objectives of our approved pest strategy. Park visitors play a crucial role in this effort and are kindly reminded to securely store their food and rubbish. This simple action helps prevent attracting pests and exacerbating the issue, ensuring a safer and healthier environment for all park users.

Further information on the Department’s Management programs for Pest plants and animals can be found at - https://parks.desi.qld.gov.au/management/programs/pest-plants-animals

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

For your safety please avoid interaction with the wildlife.

alerts.title: Changes to Scenic Rim Trail end point
alerts.description: Due to restoration works on the Cunningham Highway, changes to the Scenic Rim Trail end point at The Crest carpark are in place.
alerts.details:
Due to restoration works on the Cunningham Highway, changes to the Scenic Rim Trail end point at The Crest carpark are in place.

Access to The Crest carpark is closed to all traffic. There will be no access to the carpark for visitors to be picked up/dropped off.

The Scenic Rim Trail will now end at West Gap Creek picnic area, a further 2.5km on from The Crest carpark.

Approaching the southern end of the Scenic Rim Trail, visitors will be directed to continue past The Crest carpark to the West Gap Creek picnic area via the Box Forest track. 

This will add an additional 2.5km to the final day of the Scenic Rim Trail, for a total 15.8km walk from Banshee walkers’ camp to West Gap Creek picnic area.  

Toilet facilities at The Crest will remain open for visitors using walking tracks.

Visitors are reminded that parking along the Cunningham Highway is prohibited. 

Facilities will reopen when construction is completed.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please monitor Queensland Traffic for updated information regarding road and traffic conditions.

alerts.title: Nearshore landslide Inskip Peninsula
alerts.description: Nearshore landslides are a common occurrence on the north facing beachfront of the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.
alerts.details:
Nearshore landslides are a common occurrence on the north facing beachfront of the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.

Campers and pedestrians should exercise caution and check access conditions as landslides can occur anywhere at any time. This is part of ongoing natural coastal erosion. 

For your safety and to avoid injuries:

  • Keep well back from sand cliffs and waters’ edge as unstable beach sand may collapse without warning.
  • Avoid swimming or wading around the landslide.
  • Be aware that submerged objects and strong underwater currents may be present.
  • Nearby trees or branches may fall at any time.
  • Supervise children at all times on the beach.
  • Observe all signage, barriers, and directions from Rangers, and do not enter closed areas.

Ensure compliance with any signage for your safety.

Report any unstable beach activity to 07 3087 8910.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Planned burns are undertaken to help protect life and property in the event of a wildfire and to maintain healthy forests.

Smoke may be seen in the vicinity of Nerang – Murwillumbah Road and Binna Burra Road.

Persons with respiratory or other health problems should seek medical advice on mitigating the effects of smoke inhalation.

Walkers using the Gold Coast Hinterland Great walk on the day of the planned burn will be able to get through, however should expect short delays until ranger give the all clear to proceed when safe.

During the planned burn the follow area will be closed to public access:

  • The Lower Bellbird track

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers, and do not enter closed areas.

Apply for a QPWS camping permit refund online at www.qld.gov.au/camping. Log into your account and cancel your booking up to two days before your booking commences to receive an automatic refund or alternatively apply for a refund.

alerts.title: Cassowary safety message: Murray Falls, Girramay National Park
alerts.description: Please see below cassowary safety information for visitors to Murray Falls, Girramay National Park.
alerts.details:
Please see below cassowary safety information for visitors to Murray Falls, Girramay National Park.

  • While cassowaries are fascinating, they are also potentially dangerous.  The cassowaries at Murray Falls camping area are very bold and will actively take food from campers.
  • Please ensure all food, scraps and rubbish is secured and not accessible to cassowaries.  Extra vigilance is required around mealtimes.
  • Allowing cassowaries to connect human campsites with food is dangerous to campers and may lead to illness, injury, and deaths of birds.
  • Rangers and wildlife officers are regularly visiting the park to provide education to campers regarding cassowary behaviour and ensuring potential food sources are isolated.  

Visitors are reminded to Be CassoWARY when visiting the park.

alerts.description: The Seasonal Shorebird Closure Areas at Moon Point, Maaroom, Boonooroo, and Cooloola are in place each year from: (a) 1st March to 30th April; and (b) 1st September to 31st October. Unauthorised entry and domestic animals are prohibited during these times. The area is closed to minimise the harm or distress to shorebirds caused, directly or indirectly, by human activity.
alerts.details:
The Seasonal Shorebird Closure Areas at Moon Point, Maaroom, Boonooroo, and Cooloola are in place each year from: (a) 1st March to 30th April; and (b) 1st September to 31st October. Unauthorised entry and domestic animals are prohibited during these times. The area is closed to minimise the harm or distress to shorebirds caused, directly or indirectly, by human activity.

Penalties, including on-the-spot fines apply.

More Information on the locations of these areas can be found at www.qld.gov.au/GSMPzoning .

alerts.details:
Lawn Hill Gorge experienced widespread flooding in 2023, resulting in extensive damage to visitor facilities and critical park infrastructure.

Significant remediation works are now underway. For your safety, the Lawn Hill Gorge section of Boodjamulla National Park (Aboriginal Land) remains closed to visitors to allow for the extensive flood recovery reconstruction and maintenance work to continue safely.

Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and the Waanyi People look forward to welcoming you back to Lawn Hill Gorge in mid-2025.

We appreciate your patience and apologise for any inconvenience.

For more information regarding the flood event, and the area's recovery, see: Boodjamulla flood recovery.

alerts.title: Conway National Park planned burn activities
alerts.description: Planned Burn Swamp Bay section Conway National Park
alerts.details:
Planned Burn Swamp Bay section Conway National Park

The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Partnerships (QPWS&P) will conduct planned burn operations on the Swamp Bay section of Conway National Park and Conway Conservation Park from Tuesday 20 August 2024 to Friday 23 August 2024, weather permitting, as part of the annual hazard reduction and conservation management program for parks and forests.

As a result, smoke may be seen in the local areas and beyond. Smoke can decrease visibility, so it is important that motorists, mariners, and pilots drive/fly safely to the conditions.

For public safety, access to the planned burn area will be closed until further notice. All walking tracks, shared trails, camping areas and associated carparks within the planned burn area are closed, including:

  • Mt Rooper circuit
  • Swamp Bay walk
  • Swamp Bay camping area

The aim of this burn is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas. This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural forest regeneration.

Local residents should close windows and doors and keep medications close by if suffering from a respiratory illness

For more information, please contact QPWS&P on 13QGOV (13 74 68).

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Safety advice: heavy rain impacts Josephine Creek and Falls, Wooroonooran National Park
alerts.description: Visitors are advised that Josephine Creek at Josephine Falls in Wooroonooran National Park is closed until further notice. Heavy rain has resulted in fast flowing, high water levels in Josephine Creek. Further rain is expected. Water levels can change rapidly in Josephine Creek. For your safety, do not enter the water. The walking track and viewing platforms can still be accessed but the creek is closed.

alerts.title: Planned burns: Princess Hills, Blencoe Falls and Wairuna sections, Girringun National Park
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will conduct planned burning activities (weather permitting) within Girringun National Park from Thursday 22 August to Saturday 24 August 2024 (dates inclusive) as part of the annual hazard reduction/ conservation management program for parks and forests. As a result, smoke may be seen in the area.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will conduct planned burning activities (weather permitting) within Girringun National Park from Thursday 22 August to Saturday 24 August 2024 (dates inclusive) as part of the annual hazard reduction/ conservation management program for parks and forests. As a result, smoke may be seen in the area.

The aim of this burn is to reduce the volume of forest fuels and to create a mosaic pattern of burnt and unburnt areas.

This will help reduce the intensity of any subsequent wildfires and provide favourable conditions for natural regeneration.

Smoke can decrease visibility on the roads, so it is important that motorists drive safely to the conditions.

For more information, please call Princess Hills base office of QPWS on 4097 1448

alerts.title: Temporary walking track closures due to impacts from ex-Tropical Cyclone Jasper: Earl Hill Conservation Park
alerts.description: Due to impacts from ex-Tropical Cyclone Jasper, some walking tracks at Earl Hill Conservation Park remain closed due to landslips. See below for more information on Earl Hill Conservation Park walking tracks. The Woodland walking track is partially closed. The section from the trailhead on Flagship Drive up to the junction with the Rainforest walking track is closed. From the junction to the summit is open and can be accessed from the Rainforest walking track. The partial closure is due to a landslip that requires earth stabilisation work to make it safe.
alerts.details:
Due to impacts from ex-Tropical Cyclone Jasper, some walking tracks at Earl Hill Conservation Park remain closed due to landslips. From the junction to the summit is open and can be accessed from the Rainforest walking track. The partial closure is due to a landslip that requires earth stabilisation work to make it safe.

The following Earl Hill Conservation Park walking tracks are OPEN:

  • Cycad walking track
  • Rainforest walking track
  • Lizard walking track.

A map of Earl Hill Conservation Park walking tracks can be found here.
Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.
Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.
